messageBody:
Well you could always try Doe, Ray, Me, etc.
I don't think I could say 'Middle Doe' with a straight face though - it
just sounds so silly :).
And I doubt you'd get many musicians willing to switch.

On acronyms I don't see much change from the status quo - I mean what's
the difference between F-dot-B-dot-I and F-namingdot-B-namingdot-I?
As you say they both take the same amount of time to write and type.
Lots of people don't even bother with the dots and just rely on context
- I doubt things would be much different in Quikscript.

I didn't expect anyone to know xkb, I was just asking in case we had an
X guru hanging around.
I have a few ideas still to try and if that doesn't work out I'll try
and get help on a X related mailing list/site/channel.

I'm using a similar method to your wife's, pressing the left and right
alt keys toggles the keymap (well actually it causes a dialog to pop up
with an error message, but it would work if I could figure out the syntax).

The keys list is a list of Quikscript letters sorted by frequency.
The loops pull a letter off the key list and assigns it to the next
'best' key until there are no keys left.

There is a utility (xkbprint) which takes a xkb description and makes an
image from it, but since I haven't got it right yet it just gives me an
error message.
I'll upload an image when I get it working.

oliver langan wrote:
>
> I agree with PhD: Latin is not going anywhere, and in fact it is a
> great alphabet for many languages (especially Italian and Spanish,
> French not so much so). It is not too jarring to mix standard
> orthography and Quickscript, so when referring to something in 'the
> key of F flat' the F could remain written in Latin. Acronyms are the
> same, though if we are not careful we will get ourselves into exactly
> the same situation as the Japanese where up to four writing systems
> are intermixed constantly (Kanji, Hiragana, Katakana, Romaji/Latin).
> I would hate to see what a Japanese/Arabic dictionary looks like ;)
>
> Alternately, new acronyms could be made up: but how to distinguish
> them as acronyms? "Fie-Bay-It" is just as easy to say as "FBI" but
> the idea of putting a name dot in front of each character is
> unappealing: "dot fie dot bay dot it" is certainly no easier to write
> than the Latin version. And as PhD points out, often the acronyms are
> more well known than the names themselves, anyway. Personally, I vote
> for the mix: QS + Latin characters.
>
> amd64_hacker, I am not familiar with xkb, sorry; but I have been
> successful in making keyboard maps on Mac OS X. That is how I have
> been entering unicode in my tests, recently, and I have to admit that
> my own keyboard map (in the files section) is good but not great: it
> requires too much use of the shift key. Also, when it is active, none
> of the hot-keys work as I expect them to (command-x, etc.), since
> those letters have been remapped. I think a good way to go might be
> like my wife's Chinese-input keyboard: when the caps-lock key is down,
> it types Latin characters; when up, it types strokes which get
> assembled into full characters. In our case, a keyboard mapping which
> is standard Latin + numbers normally, but Quickscript when Caps Lock
> is down, would be ideal: it could be left on virtually all the time (I
> never use the Caps Lock myself, in fact having remapped it to act like
> a second control key).
>
> I looked at your perl script, but I can't make out the actual mapping:
> does the hex code in @keys refer to its current or new mapping? Any
> way we could get a more visual example?
>
> oliver
>
>
